About This Game

Kane and Lynch: Dead Men is the new action shooter franchise by Io-Interactive, creators of the multi-million selling Hitman series. Kane & Lynch: Dead Men follows the violent and chaotic journey of two men - a flawed mercenary and a medicated psychopath - and their brutal attitude towards right and wrong. This volatile partnership combined with innovative technologies allow for an unparalleled gaming experience.
Kane & Lynch: Dead Men immerses players in an emotionally intense crime drama with unflinching action. Io-Interactive's proprietary technology delivers fluid high definition graphics and lighting; highly destructible environments; massive crowd AI; single, co-op, and squad-based combat; a cinematic interface; and non-stop dialog between Kane and Lynch. The title also features innovative two-player co-op and groundbreaking online game play.
  • Tense and unpredictable experience - This is the violent and chaotic journey of two men: a flawed mercenary and a medicated psychopath. Each hates the other but must work together to save themselves and possibly the ones they love. Play Kane in single-player mode and either character in two-player co-op mode.
  • Violence erupts in meticulously created 'safe' worlds - Realistic and responsive environments and crowds react when events get of out control. Crowded nightclubs and calm bank offices become scenes of sudden terror. Manipulate the environments and crowds strategically to complete objectives.
  • Wide variety of intense 3rd person game play - Rappel from buildings; fire on the run or from moving vehicles; launch surprise attacks, lay down cover fire, and shoot blind from around corners; and hurl smoke, tear, and incendiary grenades.
  • Fast and intuitive combat - Lead a crew of criminal mercenaries to increase your chance of surviving and reaching your goals. You can also fight alone as your crew AI will automatically draw fire, throw grenades, lay down cover, and engage in close combat with their own signature moves.
  • Two-player co-operative game play - Team up and play the full story with a friend as either Kane or Lynch. On the big jobs, split the command of your crew. At any point in the game you can choose to play the next, or previous, levels in co-op.
  • Innovative multi-player levels based on the game's themes for up to eight players.
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum configuration
    (800x600, detail reduced)
    • OS: Windows XP Service Pack 2, Windows Vista
    • Processor: Intel Pentium 4 2Ghz or AMD Athlon XP 1800+
    • RAM: 1GB
    • Video card: 128 MB NVIDIA 6600 or better/ATI X1300 or better
    • HARD DRIVE SPACE: 7GB
    • INPUT DEVICES: 100% Windows 2000/XP compatible mouse and keyboard
    Recommended configuration
    (Up to 1280x960, all features on)
    • Processor: Intel Pentium 4 2.5Ghz or AMD Athlon XP 2400+
    Optimum configuration
    (1600x1200, all features on)
    • Processor: Intel Pentium 4 3Ghz or AMD Athlon XP 3000+
    • RAM: 2GB
    • Video card: 128 MB NVIDIA 8300 or better/ATI X1800 or better
    • INPUT DEVICES: 100% Windows 2000/XP compatible mouse and keyboard or Xbox 360-compatible controller

Kaneki Ken
80 products in account
65 reviews
Recommended
44.5 hrs on record
Posted: May 10
Kane & Lynch: Dead Men, directly from the darkest recesses of the minds of the children of IO Interactive, creators of Hitman and Freedom Fighters underestimated, is a title difficult and inconvenient to evaluate. Difficult because it is full of good ideas unfortunately not always well done, uncomfortable because in these times of mania censorship and witch hunt, is a game that does everything to be tipped as amoral and violent. Stuff to embarrass any GTA.
If Tommy Vercetti and Carl Johnson could be sympathetic in their raids towns, Kane & Lynch on the contrary are the classic antiheroes, two shady characters sadistic and ruthless than any other video game or movie would be the perfect antagonists. There is nothing heroic about them, there is no possibility that it clicks a minimum of empathy for the two hardened criminals.
In most hate and detest and do nothing to hide: their constant foul language is there to prove it. Killers and robbers without remorse, killing machines rated the massacre without respect for anyone. The beginning of the story is withering. The two are, from complete strangers on the bus that takes them to death row when they are freed by an armed part of the gang called "The Seven". Kane, accused of stealing their money, will take a few days to bring them back, otherwise he will be killed the family.
What's more the flank Lynch, a schizophrenic tangled with slight problems of self-control, to watch him and help him in the mission impossible.
From this moment everything that moves, especially when wearing a blue uniform and a star on the chest, it is shot down regardless. Traveling between California and Japan, attacking banks, skyscrapers and even becoming street in a crowded nightclub, all told by their voices and cut scenes made with the game engine, exquisitely cut film

TheEngiGuy
367 products in account
26 reviews
Recommended
9.1 hrs on record
Posted: June 26
This game is so underrated and misunderstood. It got a bad reputation mainly because of the Gamespot controversy, but that doesn't mean the game itself is bad because of it. I don't know what else to say other than it being a generic cover-based shooter, so let's get to the pros and cons.

PROS
+ Kane and Lynch are awesome characters and what make this franchise memorable.
+ Each level is different, all set in impressive locations: bank heist, skyscraper, prison break... heck, even civil war.
+ Shootouts are very intense, combined with Jesper Kyd, Peter Peter and Peter Kyed's musical score.
+ Not a weak storyline.
+ Clean and "realistic" graphics (meaning that it is not full of post-process effects like many games nowadays).
+ Splitscreen co-op.

CONS
- No online co-op
- Single-player campaign is short.
- Multiplayer, as innovative and fun as it was, it is actually dead.
- Clunky gameplay and gunplay.
- AI has some issues that sometimes break the immersion.
- You have to manually install GFWL through the game's folder, you do not need an account to play though.

I do recommend it, especially if you have a buddy to play co-op with. Like Heat, this game has some memorable shootouts and the characters are "unlikeable" on purpose that ♥♥♥♥ everything up.

Personal rating: 7/10

who cares if the characters say "♥♥♥♥" all the time?

thejackalinthetor
1,972 products in account
3 reviews
Recommended
7.3 hrs on record
Posted: May 11
I'm not going to pretend that this game is perfect. Read enough of the other reviews and you will clearly see that people are mixed on this game. I'm also not going to touch on the review scandal. That was an ugly bit of business, but it doesn't impact the game on its own merits. It showcases how scummy the company is that made the game.

I like the characters overall. The gang of mercs that you build up has their own personalities and each one adds to the story a little bit, but the center is on Kane and Lynch. The banter between these 2 during the course of a mission can be a lot of fun to listen to and it helps drive the story a little bit further. Games like this usually don't have much of a story to them, but this one has little pockets waiting to be seen, if you give it a chance.

It's not without issues, though. The cover system, while functional at times, does not always work and sometimes you will snap into cover at odd angles or stupid moments and it won't work when you always need it to. Gunfire definitely drives your aim skyward, but that is a relaistic idea (even if it seems too aggressive in this game). Enemies do take a fair number of hits to put them down, but if you're in that much of a bad situation, you can always switch to your pistol and go for headshots.

The music and sound effects are great and, again, the banter between the characters will keep things moving. Sure, profanity abounds in this, but given the source material, what did you expect?

Overall, a mix of locations (and the club shows how many people you can put on a screen at one time... nice chaotic atmosphere that makes it harder to get by without killing any innocents) keeps things interesting and varied. There aren't too many guns, but there are enough to get the job done and give you a little freedom to determine what works best for you.

Is it perfect? Hell no. Will you get frustrated with the things that don't work well? Quite possibly. But is it worth giving it a try to enjoy what does work? Yes, I think it is.
